object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.2.1.1.17 (Deprecate/Retract Record Entry Audit Trigger), including specified metadata.

object.name: RI.1.1.18 Re-Activate Record Entries
object.notes: $ST$Re-activate Record Entries (1 or more instances)$DE$Occurs when Record Entries are made active again after previously Destroy or Deprecate.• Re-activation of Record Entries may be initiated by User command.• Re-activation of Record Entries is the responsibility of the System – which invokes relevant rules.• An Audit Trigger is initiated to track Record Entry Re-Activation.$EX$

object.name: RI.1.1.18#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to re-activate (previously deleted or deprecated) Record Entries according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.1.18#02
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.2.1.1.18 (Re-Activate Record Entry Audit Trigger), including specified metadata.

object.name: RI.1.1.19 Merge Record Entries
object.notes: $ST$Merge Record Entries (2 or more instances)$DE$Occurs when Record Entries are merged together. • Entries may be merged if duplicate patient records are found.$EX$

object.name: RI.1.1.19#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to logically merge patient Record Entries according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.1.19#02
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.2.1.1.19 (Merge Record Entry Audit Trigger), including specified metadata.

object.name: RI.1.1.20 Unmerge Record Entries
object.notes: $ST$Unmerge previously merged Record Entries (2 or more instances)$DE$Occurs when Record Entries must be unmerged from previous merge, as in RI.1.1.16.$EX$

object.name: RI.1.1.20#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to unmerge multiple patient Record Entries according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.1.20#02
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.2.1.1.20 (Unmerge Record Entry Audit Trigger), including specified metadata.

object.name: RI.1.1.21 Link Record Entries
object.notes: $ST$Link Record Entries (2 or more instances)$DE$Occurs when Record Entries are linked together. • Entries may be linked for a single an encounter (patient visit)• Entries may be linked for an episode (patient problem)• Entries may be linked for a selected population cohort$EX$

object.name: RI.1.1.21#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to logically link patient Record Entries according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.1.21#02
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.2.1.1.21 (Link Record Entry Audit Trigger), including specified metadata.

object.name: RI.1.1.22 Unlink Record Entries
object.notes: $ST$Unlink previously linked Record Entries (2 or more instances)$DE$Occurs when Record Entries must be unlinked from previous linkage, as in RI.1.1.18.$EX$

object.name: RI.1.1.22#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to unlink multiple patient Record Entries according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.1.22#02
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.2.1.1.22 (Unlink Record Entry Audit Trigger), including specified metadata.

object.name: RI.1.1.23 Place Record Entries on Legal Hold
object.notes: $ST$Hold Record Entries in an unaltered state for legal hold period (1 or more instances)$DE$Occurs when Record Entries must be marked (and held in an unaltered state) for purposes of a legal hold (typically as the result of court or legal action).$EX$

object.name: RI.1.1.23#01
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function RI.1.2.2 (Manage Record Entries for Legal Hold).

object.name: RI.1.1.23#02
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to manage a specified set of patient Record Entries during period of legal hold, marking as to on hold status and preventing alteration.

object.name: RI.1.1.23#03
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.2.1.1.23 (Place Legal Hold on Record Entry Audit Trigger), including specified metadata.

object.name: RI.1.1.24 Release Record Entries from Legal Hold
object.notes: $ST$Release legal hold on Record Entries (1 or more instances)$DE$Occurs when Record Entries are released from legal hold (previously marked and held in unaltered state), as in RI.1.1.20.$EX$

object.name: RI.1.1.24#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to release patient Record Entries from legal hold status.

object.name: RI.1.1.24#02
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.2.1.1.24 (Remove Legal Hold on Record Entry Audit Trigger), including specified metadata.

object.name: RI.1.2 Record Lifespan
object.notes: $ST$Manage Record Lifespan$DE$Record Lifecycle Events (Section RI.1.1) are those required to manage Record Entries in persistent storage over the full course of Record Lifespan (Section RI.1.2). See Section RI.1.1, Record Lifecycle, for further description.$EX$

object.name: RI.1.2.1 Manage Record Entries
object.notes: $ST$Manage/Persist Record Entries (Multiple instances)$DE$Occurs upon Record Entry origination/retention and thereafter on a continuous and uninterrupted basis for lifespan of each Record Entry.• Ensures long-term retention and preservation of EHR Record Entries, without alteration.Reference: ISO 21089, Section 12.2.2$EX$

object.name: RI.1.2.1#01
object.notes: The system SHALL manage each Record Entry as a persistent, indelible (unalterable) data object, including its revision history.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#02
object.notes: The system SHALL manage (persist) each Record Entry for its applicable retention period according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#03
object.notes: The system SHALL manage (persist) the full set of identity, event and provenance Audit Metadata for each Record Entry, conforming to lifecycle events in function RI.1.1 (Record Lifecycle) and metadata requirements in function TI.2.1.1 (Record Entry Audit Triggers).

object.name: RI.1.2.1#04
object.notes: The system SHALL manage (persist) the attestation/signature event (e.g., digital signature) of each Record Entry conforming to function RI.1.1.4 (Attest Record Entry Content).

object.name: RI.1.2.1#05
object.notes: The system SHALL manage Record Entries with data content in standard and non-standard formats.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#06
object.notes: The system SHALL manage Record Entries containing both structured and unstructured data.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#07
object.notes: The system SHOULD manage Record Entry content with tagged or delimited elements including data formatted as text, documents, images, audio, waveforms, in ASCII, binary and other encodings.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD manage Record Entries in clinical and business contexts.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#09
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage sets of clinical and business context data, to be captured in or linked to Record Entries.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#10
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to extract all available elements included in the definition of a legal medical record (including Audit Log Entries and the decoded translation of anything stored only in code form) according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#11
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to tag specific Record Entries for deletion according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#12
object.notes: IF allowing tags for specific Record Entry deletion, THEN the system SHALL provide the ability to manage the set of tagged Entries, allowing review and confirmation before actual deletion occurs according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#13
object.notes: IF allowing tags for specific Record Entry deletion, THEN the system SHALL provide the ability to delete Entries according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#14
object.notes: IF allowing tags for specific Record Entry deletion, THEN the system SHALL provide the ability to render confirming notification that the destruction occurred according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#15
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to undelete Record Entries according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#16
object.notes: The system MAY transmit record destruction date information along with existing data when transmitting Record Entries (or extracts) to another entity.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#17
object.notes: The system SHOULD manage health care information for organizations that have multiple facilities according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#18
object.notes: The system MAY tag and render patient information that has been not been previously presented to the clinician.

object.name: RI.1.2.1#19
object.notes: IF the system tags patient information from internal or external systems that has not been previously presented to the clinician, THEN the system MAY present a notification to that clinician in accordance with user role and according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.2.2 Manage Record Entries for Legal Hold
object.notes: $ST$Manage/Preserve Record Entries for Legal Hold (Multiple instances)$DE$Occurs when a set of Record Entries is designated to be held for legal purposes or proceedings. • Ensures preservation of a set of Record Entries for a designated time, held without alteration.$EX$

object.name: RI.1.2.2#01
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function RI.1.1.23 (Place Record Entries on Legal Hold).

object.name: RI.1.2.2#02
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function RI.1.1.24 (Release Record Entries from Legal Hold).

object.name: RI.1.2.2#03
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to control access to data/records during legal hold, preventing un-auditable alteration or unauthorized use for preservation purposes.

object.name: RI.1.2.2#04
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to maintain records beyond normal retention period according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.2.2#05
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to capture the reason for preserving records beyond the normal retention period.

object.name: RI.1.2.2#06
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to render a legal hold notice identifying who to contact for questions when a user attempts to alter a record on legal hold.

object.name: RI.1.2.2#07
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to render Record Entry content preserved for a legal hold by type, class or encounter (e.g., medical Record Entry or report, e-mail, metadata, etc.), conforming to function RI.1.1.13 (Extract Record Entry Content).

object.name: RI.1.3 Record States
object.notes: $ST$Manage Record States$DE$Record Entries may reside in various states that must be managed. An important underlying principle for managing record states is the need to retain Record Entries that have been viewed for patient care purposes even if the Entry has not been completed or attested. This principle has important legal impact because it provides an account of what the provider viewed and relied on for clinical decision-making. For example, if Record Entry content was available in pending state and a clinician used the information to make decisions, it is important to retain the pending version even after the final version was available. Determining if Record Entry content was used for patient care may be challenging. Access logs could provide a mechanism to determine if the information was used.$EX$

object.name: RI.1.3.1 Manage Record Pending State
object.notes: $ST$Manage Record Entries during the various states of completion.$DE$Record Entries may reside in various states that must be managed. An important underlying principle for managing record states is the need to retain Record Entries that have been viewed for patient care purposes even if it has not been completed or attested. This principle has important legal impact because it provides a record of what the provider relied on for clinical decision-making. For example, if a Record Entry was available in pending state and a clinician accessed the information to make decisions, it is important to retain the pending version even after the final version was available. Determining if the Record Entry was accessed for patient care may be challenging. Access logs should show if the information was accessed/viewed.$EX$

object.name: RI.1.3.1#01
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage the length of time a Record Entry can be in a pending or inactive state before being administratively closed.

object.name: RI.1.3.1#02
object.notes: The system MAY present a notification to the author or designate that a Record Entry will be administratively closed after a designated period of time.

object.name: RI.1.3.1#03
object.notes: The system MAY present pending Record Entries in accordance with the organization’s business rules.

object.name: RI.1.3.1#04
object.notes: IF the system displays pending Record Entries, THEN the system SHALL tag and present that a Record Entry is pending or incomplete.

object.name: RI.1.3.1#05
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to update a Record Entry status to one of:- complete, - complete while retaining incomplete version of the Entry if viewed for patient care or used by the system, - mark as erroneous and retain if Entry used for patient care or by the system, or - discard if Entry never viewed for patient care purposes.

object.name: RI.1.3.1#06
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage administrative closure of a Record Entry after a period of inactivity according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.1.3.1#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture a date/time stamp and identify the author each time a Record Entry is updated including when opened, when updated, with the signature event and when officially closed, conforming to function TI.2.1.1 (Record Entry Audit Triggers).

object.name: RI.1.3.2 Manage Record Entry Amended, Corrected and Augmented State
object.notes: $ST$Manage Record Entries amended, corrected or augmented after finalization (or signature/attestation).$DE$Clinicians need the ability to correct, amend or augment Record Entries once they have been completed. When an amendment, correction or augmentation has been made, principles for documentation practices require that the original documentation must be accessible, readable, and unobliterated. A user must have a clear indication that modifications have been made to an Record Entry. There is optionality in how a system may identify a Record Entry that has been corrected or amended – a flag or indicator could be displayed, the text could be in a different font, etc. The original Record Entry is not required to be displayed, but can be linked or traced back. The original Record Entry and each successive amendment, correction or augmentation should be retained for the legally prescribed timeframe as defined by scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.$EX$

object.name: RI.1.3.2#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to update a Record Entry for purposes of amendment, correction or augmentation, conforming to function RI.1.1.2 (Amend Record Entry Content).

object.name: RI.1.3.2#02
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to tag a Record Entry as an amendment, a correction of erroneous information and the reason, or an augmentation to supplement content.

object.name: RI.1.3.2#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture, maintain and render the corresponding date, time and user specifying when and by whom a Record Entry was amended, corrected or augmented, conforming to function TI.2.1.1.2 (Amend Record Entry Audit Trigger).

object.name: RI.1.3.2#04
object.notes: The system SHALL present the current version and provide a link or clear direction for accessing previous version(s) of the Record Entry.

object.name: RI.1.3.2#05
object.notes: The system SHALL manage all versions of the Record Entry for the legal retention period, conforming to function RI.1.2.1 (Manage Record Entries).

object.name: RI.1.3.3 Manage Record Entry Succession and Version Control
object.notes: $ST$Manage successive Record Entry versions over time.$DE$The system must have a mechanism to handle versions and succession of Record Entries (such as a preliminary and final lab reports, amended or corrected documents). Versioning and succession management is based on Record Entry content and/or status change over time.A version may be one of:1) A completed and attested Record Entry; 2) A Record Entry completed and attested which has been modified one or more times3) A Record Entry that has been viewed for clinical decision-making purposes by an individual other than the author4) A Record Entry that has been captured in an incomplete state per organization business rules and updated over time (i.e., a preliminary lab test). 5) A Record Entry that electively, according to the author, must be preserved in the current state at a given point in time (i.e., History and Physical). Certain types of Record Entries are typically handled in versions, for example:- Lab results (preliminary and final)- Dictated reports- Work ups (over course of days)The prior version of Record Entries should be retained for the legally prescribed timeframe as defined by scope of practice, organizational policy and jurisdictional law.$EX$

object.name: RI.1.3.3#01
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage Record Entries that become new versions when their state changes (e.g. augmented, amended, corrected, etc.).

object.name: RI.1.3.3#02
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to update a Record Entry and save it as a new version.

object.name: RI.1.3.3#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture, maintain and render the date, time and user for the original and each updated version(s) of the Record Entry.

object.name: RI.1.3.3#04
object.notes: The system SHALL manage the succession of Record Entries in chronological version order.

object.name: RI.1.3.4 Manage Record Entry Retraction
object.notes: $ST$Remove a record entry from view if it is deemed erroneous and cite the reason.$DE$Record retraction is used to reverse changes that have been made to existing Record Entries. Once a Record Entry has been retracted, it is no longer visible in standard queries, though it remains accessible in EHR audit records should evidence ever be required for legal or other exceptional circumstances.Canada Health Infoway provides the following definition for retraction: This mechanism allows an existing record to be “removed” from the EHR if it is deemed erroneous. It can also be used to reverse changes that have been made to an existing record. Once a record has been retracted, it is no longer visible in standard queries, though it remains accessible in EHR audit records should evidence ever be required for legal or other exceptional circumstances. After retracting an erroneous record, a user has the ability to resubmit a corrected record with no visible indication that there was ever a previous version. Retract generally has significant constraints upon its use because of the risks of removing data from a patient’s record that might have been used by others in making decisions. The specifics will vary by jurisdiction, and potentially even by type of data.There are times that a EHR Record Entry is created then found to be erroneous, i.e., the record may belong to another individual. In these cases, it is necessary to remove that record from view (storing it in case it may be needed for litigation or investigation purposes, etc.). After retracting an erroneous record, a user has the ability to resubmit a corrected record with no visible indication that there was ever a previous version.$EX$

object.name: RI.1.3.4#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to hide a Record Entry from view and retain it such that it is only visible upon specific request and with appropriate authorization.

object.name: RI.1.3.4#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to capture users who viewed a Record Entry prior to its retraction and notify them of the retraction.

object.name: RI.1.3.4#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to capture and retain the reason why a Record Entry was retracted.

object.name: RI.1.3.4#04
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function RI.1.1.17 (Deprecate/Retract Record Entries).

object.name: RI.1.4 Record Completeness
object.notes: $ST$Manage Record Completeness$DE$The EHR-S must provide the ability for an organization to define minimum elements and timeframes for completion at the report level and at the record level. Provide a report that identifies completion and timeliness status by patient/ health record number or other specified parameters.Prior to disclosure for legal proceedings or other official purposes, an organization analyzes the health record for completeness. EHR systems must provide the ability to define a minimum set of content to be analyzed for timeliness and completeness and provide a report of the status.$EX$

object.name: RI.1.4#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to manage timeframes for completion of specified Record Entry content according to organizational business rules.

object.name: RI.1.4#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to tag by patient/health record number the completeness status of specified Record Entry content noting identified deficiencies.

object.name: RI.1.4#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to render a report by patient/health record number indicating the completeness status of specified Record Entry content noting identified deficiencies.

object.name: RI.1.4#04
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to render a visual indicator denoting that the content of a specified Record Entry content is incomplete according to organizational business rules.

object.name: RI.1.4#05
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to render a reminder to clinicians for the completion of specified Record Entry content (at the data or report level) according to organizational business rules (e.g., complete attestation, complete a section).

object.name: RI.2 Record Synchronization
object.notes: $ST$Manage Record Synchronization$DE$An EHR-S may consist of a set of components or applications; each application manages a subset of the health information. Therefore it is important that, through various interoperability mechanisms, an EHR-S maintains all the relevant information regarding the health record in synchrony. For example, if a physician orders an MRI, a set of diagnostic images and a radiology report will be created. As a result, the patient demographic information, the order for MRI, the diagnostic images associated with the order, and the report associated with the study must all be synchronized in order for the clinicians to receive a synchronized view the complete record (with respect to time and geographic location).Date and time need to be consistent across the applications that are part of the EHR system.Synchronization demonstrates a sequence and chain of events for reconstruction and is relevant during a legal proceeding. Maintenance of synchronization activities could be relevant during a legal proceeding.Note: Standards exist for Consistent Date and Time.$EX$

object.name: RI.2#01
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.5.1 (Application and Structured-Document Interchange Standards).

object.name: RI.2#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD conform to function TI.3 (Registry and Directory Services).

object.name: RI.2#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to link Record Entries to external information.

object.name: RI.2#04
object.notes: The system SHOULD store the location of each known Record Entry in order to enable authorized access to a complete logical health record if the EHR is distributed among several applications, services, or devices within the EHR-S.

object.name: RI.2#05
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to manage date and time-related information between applications, components, services, systems, and devices.

object.name: RI.3 Record Archive and Restore
object.notes: $ST$Manage Record Archive and Restore$DE$EHR Record Entries must be transitioned over its lifecycle from online data structures to near-line or off-line data structures. The archive function performs this transition of Record Entries from an online, production EHR-S to offline storage for information that is not being purged/destroyed. The system must provide such archive and restore functions to extract and preserve indefinitely, Record Entries selected to be removed from the live production EHR-S database and retained.Record Entries must be archived and restored in such a manner as to permit them to be returned to their original or similar information structures. Archived Record Entries must also include corresponding metadata to ensure logical and semantic consistency of the information for subsequent access upon restoration.The archive function should provide both an automated, configurable capability as well as a user-invoked archival function to enable selected Record Entries to be preserved, or flagged for preservation. In the first instance, rules are specified to enable the system to conduct archiving in an unattended fashion. This is often the case for periodic system maintenance requirements (e.g. nightly processing where archival, data summarization and possibly purging of information occurs). In the second instance the system should provide the ability to select Record Entries to be preserved for future reference and access, such as in the case where selected Entries need to be preserved and retained for litigation.In restoring information, it may occur that Record Entries being restored are a subset of the Entries originally archived. For example, when all Record Entries for a patient encounter were archived and only a particular set of Record Entries related to a study or result are to be restored. The system may provide for such finer granularity of restoration.Archiving and restoring of Record Entries must be performed in a timely fashion, consistent with the operational requirements of both EHR users and system and technology capabilities.The system must enable compliance with records retention according to scope of practice, organizational policy or jurisdictional law.$EX$

object.name: RI.3#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to archive and restore Record Entries according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: RI.3#02
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability for an authorized user to tag Record Entries to be archived.

object.name: RI.3#03
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to archive or restore metadata that is associated with Record Entries that have been archived or restored.

object.name: RI.3#04
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to enter a target destination when restoring Record Entries (e.g., original data location, temporary user storage, or a research/analysis database).

object.name: RI.3#05
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to tag Record Entries to be archived for removed or retained from the online database in the archive process.

object.name: RI.3#06
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to enter a schedule for archive and restore processing.

object.name: RI.3#07
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to selectively restore portions of archived Record Entries.

object.name: 7 Trust Infrastructure
object.notes: $OV$The Trust Infrastructure Chapter consists of functions common to an EHR System infrastructure, particularly those functions foundational to system operations, security, efficiency and data integrity assurance, safeguards for privacy and confidentiality, and interoperability with other systems. TI functions are core and foundational to all other functions of the Model (CP, CPS, POP, AS and RI). Note extensive reference to TI functions in Overarching Criteria. TI functions may be implemented within the architecture of a single system or across a tightly coupled suite of systems (applications).All functions within the Trust Infrastructure Section have an identifier starting with “TI”.$EX$Care Provision (CP) and Care Provision Support (CPS) functions must operate in a secure electronic environment. For example, Trust Infrastructure functions provide a secure environment for the CP immunization registration query function. Subsequently a CP function reports (transmits) the child’s immunization event in a secure manner via another TI exchange function. TI functions also transparently provide other essential services, such as periodic backups of a child’s health record and an audit trail of all accesses to that record.$AC$Many TI functions are performed transparently by EHR systems – at least from the perspective of users whose role is primarily clinical. Many TI functions occur in the background without end user intervention. Other actors may interact more directly with TI functions: System Administrators (to manage and monitor system operations, configurations, backups, etc.), Security Administrators (to implement security policies for authentication, authorization, access control, audit, identity and signatures, etc.).

object.name: TI.1 Security
object.notes: $ST$Manage EHR-S security.$DE$EHR-S security consists of entity authentication, entity authorization, entity access control, patient access management, secure data exchange, attestation, patient privacy and confidentiality.$EX$

object.name: TI.1.1 Entity Authentication
object.notes: $ST$Authenticate EHR-S users and/or entities before allowing access.$DE$All entities accessing the EHR-S are subject to authentication.Examples of entity authentication, with varying levels of authentication rigor, include: - username/password;- digital certificate;- secure token;- biometrics.$EX$

object.name: TI.1.1#01
object.notes: The system SHALL authenticate entities (e.g., users, organizations, applications, components, objects, and/or devices) accessing EHR-S protected resources (e.g., functions and data) according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law, using an authentication mechanism such as an accredited Standards Development Organization-approved authentication standard (e.g. SAML, WS-Trust, Kerberos), username/password, digital certificate, secure token, biometric, or hardware-specific addressing mechanism. (See also ISO 22600.)

object.name: TI.1.1#02
object.notes: The system SHALL manage authentication data/information securely (e.g., passwords or biometric data).

object.name: TI.1.1#03
object.notes: The system SHALL maintain configurable conditions and rules which protect against invalid, possibly malicious, authentication attempts according to organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law (e.g., consecutive invalid logon attempts).

object.name: TI.1.1#04
object.notes: IF passwords are used to control access to the EHR-S, THEN the system SHALL provide the ability to maintain configurable timeframes (e.g., 180 days) for the reuse of passwords according to organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.1#05
object.notes: IF passwords are used to control access to the EHR-S, THEN the system SHALL provide the ability to maintain a configurable limit on the reuse of recently used passwords (e.g., the last 5 passwords) according to organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.1#06
object.notes: IF username/passwords are used to control access to the EHR-S, THEN the system SHALL maintain password strength rules (e.g., requiring a minimum number of characters and inclusion of alpha-numeric complexity).

object.name: TI.1.1#07
object.notes: IF passwords are used to control access to the system, THEN the system SHALL capture passwords using obfuscation techniques (e.g., during user password entry) according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.1#08
object.notes: IF passwords are used to control access to the EHR-S, THEN the system SHALL manage password reset as an administrative function.

object.name: TI.1.1#09
object.notes: IF user passwords are initially set or later reset by an administrator, the system SHALL provide the ability to update password at the next successful logon.

object.name: TI.1.1#10
object.notes: The system SHALL present limited feedback to the user during authentication.

object.name: TI.1.1#11
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to enter case-insensitive 'usernames' that contain typeable alpha-numeric characters in support of ISO-646/ECMA-6 (aka US ASCII).

object.name: TI.1.1#12
object.notes: IF passwords are used, THEN the system SHALL provide the ability to enter case-sensitive passwords that contain typeable alpha-numeric characters in support of ISO-646/ECMA-6 (aka US ASCII).

object.name: TI.1.2 Entity Authorization
object.notes: $ST$Manage set(s) of EHR-S access control permissions.$DE$Entities are authorized to use components of an EHR-S in accordance with their scope of practice within local policy or legal jurisdiction. Authorization rules provide a proper framework for establishing access permissions and privileges for the use of an EHR system, based on user, role or context. A combination of these authorization categories may be applied to control access to EHR-S resources (i.e., functions or data), including at the operating system level.- User based authorization refers to the permissions granted to access EHR-S resources based on the identity of an entity (e.g., user or software component). - Role based authorization refers to the permissions granted to access EHR-S resources based on the role of an entity. Examples of roles include: an application or device (tele-monitor or robotic); or a nurse, dietician, administrator, legal guardian, and auditor. - Context-based Authorization refers to the permissions granted to access EHR-S resources within a context, such as when a request occurs, explicit time, location, route of access, quality of authentication, work assignment, patient consents and authorization. See ISO 10181-3 Technical Framework for Access Control Standard. For example, an EHR-S might only allow supervising providers’ context authorization to attest to entries proposed by residents under their supervision.$EX$

object.name: TI.1.2#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to manage sets of access-control permissions granted to entities (e.g., users, applications, devices) based on identity, role and/or context according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.2#02
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to TI.2 (Audit) to audit authorization actions as security events.

object.name: TI.1.2#03
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to manage roles and contexts for authorization according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.2#04
object.notes: The system SHALL maintain a revision history of all entity record modifications.

object.name: TI.1.2#05
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to manage authorizations for the use of portable media in according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.3 Entity Access Control
object.notes: $ST$Manage access to EHR-S resources.$DE$To ensure access is controlled, an EHR-S must authenticate and check authorization of entities for appropriate operations.$EX$

object.name: TI.1.3#01
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.1.1 (Entity Authentication).

object.name: TI.1.3#02
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.1.2 (Entity Authorization).

object.name: TI.1.3#03
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to manage system and data access rules for all EHR-S resources according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.3#04
object.notes: The system SHALL manage the enforcement of authorizations to access EHR-S resources.

object.name: TI.1.3#05
object.notes: The system SHALL control access to EHR-S resources after a configurable period of inactivity by terminating the session, or by initiating a session lock that remains in effect until the entity re-establishes access using appropriate identification and authentication procedures, according to organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.3.1 Emergency Access Control
object.notes: $ST$Manage emergency access to EHR-S resources.$DE$The intent of Emergency Access Control is to mitigate the potential for impeding the provision of care in an emergency situation in accordance with organizational policy.For example, emergency access may include: 1) Single record entry (e.g., single lab results, single document, single view); 2) Single patient; 3) Single login session, multiple patients; 4) Site mode allowing simultaneous emergency access to all users.Logging of a user’s activities should occur in the audit record/metadata. Reports of emergency access use for follow up are critical for compliance and monitoring.$EX$

object.name: TI.1.3.1#01
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to define emergency access rules to override entity access controls.

object.name: TI.1.3.1#02
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to capture categories of emergency access criteria (e.g., 1) Single record entry such as single lab results, single document, single view; 2) Single patient; 3) Single login session, multiple patients; 4) Site mode allowing simultaneous emergency access to all users) according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.3.1#03
object.notes: The system SHALL manage emergency access by individual users based on criteria (e.g., defined rules and categories) according to organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.3.1#04
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to maintain emergency access time limits according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.3.1#05
object.notes: The system MAY present periodic reminders to a system administrator to review user's emergency access privileges.

object.name: TI.1.3.1#06
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to capture a reason for emergency access.

object.name: TI.1.3.1#07
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to render an after action report for follow up of emergency access.

object.name: TI.1.4 Patient Access Management
object.notes: $ST$Manage a patient’s access to personal health information.$DE$A healthcare delivery organization will be able to manage a patient’s ability to view his or her EHR based on organization policy or jurisdictional law. Typically, a patient or their legal representative (e.g. guardian, surrogate) has the right to view his or her EHR.$EX$

object.name: TI.1.4#01
object.notes: IF organizational policy allows patient access to the EHR-S, THEN the system SHALL conform to Function TI.1.3 (Entity Access Control).

object.name: TI.1.4#02
object.notes: IF organizational policy allows patient access to the EHR-S, THEN the system SHALL conform to Function TI.1.2 (Entity Authorization).

object.name: TI.1.5 Non-Repudiation
object.notes: $ST$Limit an EHR-S user's ability to deny (repudiate) data origination, transmission or receipt by that user.$DE$An EHR-S allows data entry to a patient's electronic health record and it can be a sender or receiver of healthcare information. Non-repudiation is a way to guarantee that the source of the data/record cannot later deny that fact; and that the sender of a message cannot later deny having sent the message; and that the recipient cannot deny having received the message. Components of non-repudiation can include:- Digital signature, which serves as a unique identifier for an individual (much like a written signature);- Confirmation service, which utilizes a message transfer agent to create a digital receipt (providing confirmation that a message was sent and/or received);- Timestamp, which proves that a document existed at a certain date and time.$EX$

object.name: TI.1.5#01
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the identity of the entity taking the action according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.5#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture time stamp of the initial entry, modification and exchange of data according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.5#03
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.2 (Audit) to prevent repudiation of data origination, transmission and receipt according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.5#04
object.notes: The system SHOULD conform to function RI.1.1.4 (Attest Record Entry Content) to ensure integrity of data and data exchange and thus prevent repudiation of data origination, transmission or receipt according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.6 Secure Data Exchange
object.notes: $ST$Secure all modes of EHR data exchange.$DE$Whenever an exchange of EHR information occurs, it requires appropriate security and privacy considerations, including data obfuscation as well as both destination and source authentication when necessary. For example, it may be necessary to encrypt data sent to remote or external destinations.$EX$

object.name: TI.1.6#01
object.notes: The system SHALL secure all modes of EHR data exchange.

object.name: TI.1.6#02
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.1.7 (Secure Data Routing).

object.name: TI.1.6#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to de-identify data.

object.name: TI.1.6#04
object.notes: The system SHALL encrypt and decrypt EHR data that is exchanged over a non-secure link.

object.name: TI.1.6#05
object.notes: IF encryption is used, THEN the system SHALL exchange data using recognized standards-based encryption mechanisms according to organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.6#06
object.notes: IF the EHR-S is the recipient of a secure data exchange, THEN the system SHOULD provide acknowledgment of receipt.

object.name: TI.1.6#07
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to determine static or dynamic addresses for known and authorized sources and destinations.

object.name: TI.1.7 Secure Data Routing
object.notes: $ST$Route electronically exchanged EHR data only to/from known and authenticated destinations/sources (according to applicable healthcare-specific rules and relevant standards).$DE$An EHR-S needs to ensure that it is exchanging EHR information with the entities (applications, institutions, directories) it expects. This function depends on entity authorization and authentication to be available in the system. For example, a physician practice management application in an EHR-S might send claim attachment information to an external entity. To accomplish this, the application must use a secure routing method, which ensures that both the sender and receiving sides are authorized to engage in the information exchange. Known sources and destinations can be established in a static setup or they can be dynamically determined. Examples of a static setup are recordings of IP addresses or recordings of DNS names. For dynamic determination of known sources and destinations systems can use authentication mechanisms as described in IN.1.1. For example, the sending of a lab order from the EHRS to a lab system within the same organization usually uses a simple static setup for routing. In contrast sending a lab order to a reference lab outside of the organization will involve some kind of authentication process. Provision of a secure network infrastructure is beyond the scope of an EHR-S.$EX$

object.name: TI.1.7#01
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.1.1 (Entity Authentication) to exchange EHR data only to and from known, authenticated sources and destinations.

object.name: TI.1.7#02
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to Section TI.2 (Audit) to capture audit information about changes to the status of sources and destinations.

object.name: TI.1.8 Patient Privacy and Confidentiality
object.notes: $ST$Enable the enforcement of the applicable jurisdictional and organizational patient privacy rules as they apply to various parts of an EHR-S through the implementation of security mechanisms.$DE$Patients’ privacy and the confidentiality of EHRs are violated if access to EHRs occurs without authorization. Violations or potential violations can impose tangible economic or social losses on affected patients, as well as less tangible feelings of vulnerability and pain. Fear of potential violations discourages patients from revealing sensitive personal information that may be relevant to diagnostic and treatment services. Rules for the protection of privacy and confidentiality may vary depending upon the vulnerability of patients and the sensitivity of records. Strongest protections should apply to the records of minors and the records of patients with stigmatized conditions. Authorization to access the most sensitive parts of an EHR is most definitive if made by the explicit and specific consent of the patient. Please see the definition of masking in the glossary.Organizational practices related to privacy and security jurisdictional laws could be called into question during a legal proceeding. Adherence to applicable laws supports the credibility and trustworthiness of the organization.$EX$

object.name: TI.1.8#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to maintain compliance with requirements for patient privacy and confidentiality according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law (e.g., US HIPAA Privacy Rules, US Federal Conditions of Participation for Medicare/Medicaid Providers).

object.name: TI.1.8#02
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.1.1 (Entity Authentication).

object.name: TI.1.8#03
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.1.2 (Entity Authorization).

object.name: TI.1.8#04
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.1.3 (Entity Access Control).

object.name: TI.1.8#05
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.1.5 (Non-Repudiation).

object.name: TI.1.8#06
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.1.6 (Secure Data Exchange).

object.name: TI.1.8#07
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.2 (Audit).

object.name: TI.1.8#08
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to maintain varying levels of confidentiality in accordance with users' role and according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.8#09
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to mask parts of the electronic health record (e.g., medications, conditions, sensitive documents) from disclosure in accordance with users' role and according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.8#10
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to unmask (override a mask) in emergency or other specific situations in accordance with users' role, and according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.8#11
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to maintain indicators (flags) to health record users that content has been masked in accordance with users' role, and according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.8#12
object.notes: IF the system allowed a user to unmask (override a mask) in emergency or other specific situations THEN the system SHALL provide the ability to collect the reason for the override.

object.name: TI.1.8#13
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to manage patient consents to, or restrictions against, any use of data.

object.name: TI.1.8#14
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to manage a privacy policy in accordance with users' role, and according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.8#15
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to control access by specified user(s) to a particular patient health record either by inclusion or exclusion.

object.name: TI.1.8.1 Redact Patient Identifying Information
object.notes: $ST$Maintain patient identities and conditions invisible to the public and other providers who do not have “need to know” on public tracking screens. $DE$A number of systems implement large tracking screens, common displays or dashboards to support workflows. In these applications, there is a need to create de-identified views for broadcast in common areas.$EX$

object.name: TI.1.8.1#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to manage redaction of patient identities on publicly viewable status boards according to organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.8.2 Protect Individual Patient Identity
object.notes: $ST$Flag patient identity as confidential to others.$DE$Create a flag to indicate to all providers caring for the patient, as well as administrative staff who may receive phone calls from family members or others, the need to protect the identity of patients at risk of harm, or requesting similar anonymity. Despite best efforts of confidentiality, display should identify patients at particular risk of harm during stay (e.g. domestic violence).$EX$

object.name: TI.1.8.2#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to maintain the designation of patients who require protection of their identity from others, including family, visitors, and non participating healthcare providers.

object.name: TI.1.9 System Operation Measurements
object.notes: $ST$Manage the change of status of an external facility.$DE$A health care delivery relies on services provided by other external facilities such as laboratories or Long Term Care facilities. The status of those facilities is subject to change for example: power outage, flooding or overcapacity. Therefore, the EHR system needs to capture the status of the external facilities, notify appropriate individuals / organizations or even change the workflow based on established business rules. Change of the status of an external facility is patient safety concern because a provider may need to adjust patient care or care workflows accordingly. For example, changes of status of external facility include: laboratory no longer accredited, laboratory power outage, Long Term Care facility at overcapacity. If laboratory loses accreditation an administrator needs to be notified to adjust the workflow. If status change is anticipated on regular basis, the system may automatically trigger workflow adjustment according to established business rule that take in consideration the status of the external facility. The example for later, the local Long Term Care facility may routinely exceed the capacity on the weekends; therefore, the business rule will accommodate for automatic workflow adjustments. $EX$

object.name: TI.1.9#01
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage the change of status of an external facility.

object.name: TI.1.10 Service Availability
object.notes: $ST$Manage the ability to access, render and determine information related to Service Level Agreement.$DE$A provider may need to be aware of certain Service Level Agreement information in order to mitigate patient safety-related risks that depend on system availability or system performance.$EX$

object.name: TI.1.10#01
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage Service Level Agreement information according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.10#02
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to render system availability statistics and system performance statistics as specified in the Service Level Agreement according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.1.11 Trusted Information Exchange Environment
object.notes: $ST$Maintain a Trusted Information Exchange environment to enable common security measures among participants in the health information exchange.$DE$A Trusted Information Exchange environment facilitates protected health information exchange by employing common user authentication across multiple systems and/or organizations. A Trusted Information Exchange environment can help decrease risk and liability for participating members of the Trusted Information Exchange environment by ensuring that protected health information is consistently managed by all participants.$EX$

object.name: TI.1.11#01
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage applicable Trusted Information Exchange environment-related information according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law. (See ISO 22600, “Privilege Management and Access Control”, Part 1, “Overview and Policy Management”.)

object.name: TI.2 Audit
object.notes: $ST$Audit Key Record, Security, System and Clinical Events$DE$EHR Systems have built in audit triggers to capture key events in real-time, including events related to record management, security, system operations or performance or clinical situations.Event details, including key metadata (who, what, when, where), are captured in an Audit Log.Audit Review functions allow various methods of critical event notification as well as routine log review.Audit functions implement requirements according to scope of practice, organizational policy and jurisdictional law.$EX$

object.name: TI.2#01
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.1.3 (Entity Access Control) to limit access to audit record information to appropriate entities according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.2#02
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.1.3 (Entity Access Control) to limit access to audit record information for purposes of modification according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.2#03
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.1.3 (Entity Access Control) to limit access to audit record information for purposes of deletion according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.2.1 Audit Triggers
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Triggers$DE$EHR Systems have built in audit triggers to capture key events in real-time. Audit triggers signal key:• Record management and lifecycle events;• Security events related to system and data safeguards, both routine and exceptional;• System events related to performance and operations, both routine and exceptional.• Clinical events with special log requirements.$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit key events, as specified in TI.2.1 (Audit Triggers) and child functions, according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.2.1#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture key Audit Metadata at each Audit Trigger, as specified in TI.2.1 (Audit Triggers) and child functions, according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.2.1#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture an Audit Log Entry at each Audit Trigger as specified in TI.2.1 (Audit Triggers) according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.2.1#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the current master clock time to establish valid record date and time metadata.

object.name: TI.2.1#05
object.notes: The system MAY manage Audit Trigger logging using a common audit engine, for example, using schema and transports such as specified in the Audit Log specification of IHE Audit Trails and Node Authentication (ATNA) Profile.

object.name: TI.2.1.1 Record Entry Audit Triggers
object.notes: $ST$Manage Record Entry Audit Triggers$DE$Record Entries are managed throughout their lifespan at various points in their lifecycle. Record Entry Audit Triggers are designed to capture Record Entry related events including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1#01
object.notes: The system SHALL link an Audit Log Entry to each Record Entry according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.2.1.1#02
object.notes: The system SHALL harmonize Audit Log Entry Metadata and corresponding Record Entry Metadata to ensure they remain identical.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1 Originate/Retain Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry origination/retention.$DE$Capture Record Entry originate/retain events, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when a Record Entry is originated and retained.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization where Record Entry content is originated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the individual(s) who performed the Action documented in Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the user who entered/authored Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which originated Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#07
object.notes: IF the source of Record Entry content is a device, THEN the system SHALL capture identity of the device.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#08
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the Action as evidenced by Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#09
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., originate/retain).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#10
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time of Action occurrence as evidenced by Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#11
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time Record Entry content is originated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#12
object.notes: The system MAY capture the duration of the Action evidenced by Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#13
object.notes: The system MAY capture the physical location of the Action evidenced by Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#14
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where Record Entry content is originated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#15
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for the Action evidenced by Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#16
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for originating Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.1#17
object.notes: IF Record Entry content includes templates (boilerplate information) or copied (duplicated) information, THEN the system SHOULD capture the source of such content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.2 Amend Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry amendment.$DE$Capture Record Entry amendment events, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.2#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when a Record Entry is amended.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.2#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization where Record Entry content is amended.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.2#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of amended Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.2#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the user who entered/authored Record Entry content amendment.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.2#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which amended Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.2#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., amendment).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.2#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time Record Entry content is amended.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.2#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where Record Entry content is amended.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.2#09
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for amending Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.2#10
object.notes: The system SHALL capture a sequence identifier for amended Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.2#11
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture a reference (e.g., link, pointer) to pre-amendment data for each amended Record Entry.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.3 Translate Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry translation.$DE$Capture Record Entry translation events, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.3#01
object.notes: The system SHOULD audit each occurrence when Record Entry content is translated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.3#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization where Record Entry content is translated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.3#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of translated Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.3#04
object.notes: IF a user initiated a Record Entry content translation, THEN the system SHALL capture identity of the user initiating Record Entry content translation.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.3#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which translated Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.3#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., translation).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.3#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time Record Entry content is translated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.3#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where Record Entry content is translated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.3#09
object.notes: IF a user initiated a Record Entry translation, THEN the system MAY capture the rationale for translating Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.3#10
object.notes: The system SHALL capture a sequence identifier for translated Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.3#11
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the identifier and version of Translation Tools used for each translated Record Entry.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.3#12
object.notes: The system SHALL capture a reference (e.g., link, pointer) to pre-translation data for each Record Entry translation.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.4 Attest Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry attestation (Signature Event).$DE$Capture Record Entry attestation events, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.4#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence of Record Entry attestation (signature event).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.4#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization where Record Entry content attestation (signature event) occurred.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.4#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of attested Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.4#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the user attesting to Record Entry content (signature event).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.4#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application in which Record Entry content attestation (signature event) occurred.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.4#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., attestation/signature event).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.4#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time of Record Entry content attestation (signature event).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.4#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where Record Entry content attestation (signature event) occurred.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.4#09
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the data, document or other identifier for attested Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.5 View/Access Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry view/access.$DE$Capture Record Entry view/access events, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.5#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when Record Entry content is viewed/accessed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.5#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization where Record Entry content is viewed/accessed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.5#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of the viewed/accessed Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.5#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the user who viewed/accessed Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.5#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application in which Record Entry content is viewed/accessed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.5#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., view/access).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.5#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time Record Entry content is viewed/accessed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.5#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where Record Entry content is viewed/accessed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.5#09
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for viewing/accessing Record Entry content (e.g., emergency access).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.5#10
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the data, document or other identifier for the viewed/accessed Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.5#11
object.notes: The system MAY capture whether the data/document viewed/accessed is a primary source record (e.g., patient's record) or an aggregated report (e.g., summary report including multiple patients).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.5#12
object.notes: The system SHALL capture when a Record Entry content view/access occurrence is known to be a disclosure, according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.5#13
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture known and applicable permissions regarding Record Entry content viewed/accessed including confidentiality codes, patient consent authorizations, privacy policy pointers.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.6 Output/Report Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry output/report.$DE$Capture Record Entry output/report events, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.6#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when an output (e.g., report, screen shot) is generated from Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.6#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization where output/report is generated from Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.6#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of the Record Entry(ies) populating the output/report generated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.6#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the user who generated the output/report of Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.6#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application from which the output/report is generated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.6#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., output/report).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.6#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time the output/report is generated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.6#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where the output/report is generated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.6#09
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for generating the output/report.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.6#10
object.notes: The system MAY capture the data, document, or other identifier for the output/report generated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.6#11
object.notes: The system SHALL capture when a Record Entry content output/report occurrence is known to be a disclosure, according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.6#12
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture known and applicable permissions regarding Record Entry content output/reported including confidentiality codes, patient consent authorizations, privacy policy pointers.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.7 Disclose Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry disclosure.$DE$Capture Record Entry disclosure events, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.7#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when Record Entry content is disclosed according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.7#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization from which Record Entry content is disclosed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.7#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of Record Entry content disclosed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.7#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the user initiating disclosure of Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.7#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application from which Record Entry content is disclosed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.7#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., disclose).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.7#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time Record Entry content is disclosed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.7#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where Record Entry content is disclosed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.7#09
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture the rationale for disclosing Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.7#10
object.notes: The system MAY capture the data, document or other identifier for Record Entry content disclosed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.7#11
object.notes: The system SHALL capture that this is an occurrence when Record Entry content is known to be disclosed, according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.7#12
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture known and applicable permissions regarding Record Entry content disclosed including confidentiality codes, patient consent authorizations, privacy policy pointers.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8 Transmit Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry transmission.$DE$Capture Record Entry transmission events, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when Record Entry content is transmitted.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization from which Record Entry content is transmitted.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of Record Entry content transmitted.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the user initiating transmission of Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which transmitted Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which received Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., transmit).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#08
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time Record Entry content is transmitted.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#09
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) from which the Record Entry is transmitted/disclosed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#10
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the location (network address) to which the Record Entry is transmitted/disclosed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#11
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for transmitting Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#12
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Entry content transmitted/disclosed (e.g., original, amended, updated data).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#13
object.notes: The system MAY capture the data, document or other identifier for transmitted/disclosed Record Entry.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#14
object.notes: The system MAY capture data elements for transmitted/disclosed Record Entry.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#15
object.notes: The system SHALL capture when a Record Entry transmit occurrence is known to be a disclosure, according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.8#16
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture known and applicable permissions regarding Record Entry content transmitted including confidentiality codes, patient consent authorizations, privacy policy pointers.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.9 Receive/Retain Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry receipt/retention.$DE$Capture Record Entry receipt/retention events, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.9#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when eternally sourced Record Entry content is received and retained.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.9#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization transmitting Record Entry content received and retained.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.9#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization receiving transmitted Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.9#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of received Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.9#05
object.notes: IF the system supports user verification of receipt of externally sourced Record Entry content, THEN the system SHALL capture identity of the user accepting receipt of the transmitted Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.9#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which transmitted Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.9#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which received Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.9#08
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., receive).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.9#09
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time Record Entry content is received.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.9#10
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where the Record Entry content is received.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.9#11
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for accepting receipt of transmitted Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.9#12
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Entry content received (e.g., original, amended, updated data).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.9#13
object.notes: IF an internal identifier is assigned to data/documents received from an external source, THEN the system MAY capture the data, document or other identifier for the Record Entry received.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.9#14
object.notes: The system MAY capture data elements for the Record Entry received.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.10 De-Identify Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry de-identification.$DE$Capture Record Entry de-identification, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.10#02

object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of de-identified Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.10#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the user de-identifying Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.10#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which de-identified Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.10#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., de-identify).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.10#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time Record Entry content is de-identified.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.10#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where Record Entry content is de-identified.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.10#09
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for de-identifying Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.10#10
object.notes: The system MAY capture the data, document or other identifier for de-identified Record Entry content.

object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when a Record Entry content is pseudomynized.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.11#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization where Record Entry content is pseudomynized.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.11#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of pseudomynized Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.11#09
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for pseudomynizing Record Entry content.

object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry re-identification.$DE$Capture Record Entry re-identification, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.12#02

object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which re-identified Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.12#06

object.name: TI.2.1.1.12#09
