object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when Record Entry content is extracted.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.13#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization where Record Entry content is extracted.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.13#03

object.name: TI.2.1.1.14 Archive Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry archiving.$DE$Capture Record Entry archiving, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.14#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when Record Entry content is archived.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.14#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization where Record Entry content is archived.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.14#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of archived Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.14#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture an archive identifier for archived Record Entry content (e.g., nursing home inpatient stay from 3/15/2000 thru 6/10/2000).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.14#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the user archiving Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.14#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which archived Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.14#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., archive).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.14#10
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for archiving Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.14#11
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the set of Record Entry content to be archived.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.14#12
object.notes: The system MAY capture the data, document or other identifier for archived Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.14#13
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture the method and target media of archived Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.15 Restore Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry restoring.$DE$Capture Record Entry restoring, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.15#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when archived Record Entry content is restored.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.15#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization where Record Entry content is restored.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.15#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of restored Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.15#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture an archive identifier for restored Record Entry content (e.g., nursing home inpatient stay from 3/15/2000 thru 6/10/2000).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.15#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the user restoring Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.15#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which restored Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.15#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., restore).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.15#08
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time Record Entry content is restored.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.15#09
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) from which Record Entry content is restored.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.15#10
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for restoring Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.15#11
object.notes: The system MAY capture the data, document or other identifier for restored Record Entry content.

object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry destruction.$DE$Capture Record Entry destruction, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.16#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when Record Entry content is destroyed according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.16#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization where Record Entry content is destroyed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.16#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of destroyed Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.16#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture a destruction identifier for destroyed Record Entry content (e.g., nursing home inpatient stay from 3/15/2000 thru 6/10/2000).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.16#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the user destroying Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.16#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which destroyed Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.16#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., destroy).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.16#08
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time Record Entry content is destroyed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.16#09
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where Record Entry content is destroyed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.16#10
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for destroying Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.16#11
object.notes: The system MAY capture the data, document or other identifier for destroyed Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.16#12
object.notes: The system MAY capture data elements for Record Entry content de-identified.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.17 Deprecate/Retract Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry deprecation/retraction.$DE$Capture Record Entry deprecation/retraction, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.17#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when Record Entry content is deprecated/retracted.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.17#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization where Record Entry content is deprecated/retracted.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.17#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of deprecated/retracted Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.17#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the user deprecating/retracting Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.17#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which deprecated/retracted Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.17#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., deprecate/retract).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.17#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time Record Entry content is deprecated/retracted.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.17#08
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where Record Entry content is deprecated/retracted.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.17#09
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for deprecating/retracting Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.18 Re-Activate Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry re-Activation.$DE$Capture Record Entry re-activation, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.18#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when destroyed or deprecated Record Entry content is re-activated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.18#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization where Record Entry content is reactivated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.18#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of reactivated Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.18#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the user reactivating Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.18#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which re-activated Record Entry content.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.18#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., re-activate).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.18#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time Record Entry content is re-activated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.18#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where Record Entry content is re-activated.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.18#09
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for re-activating Record Entry content.

object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry merging.$DE$Capture Record Entry merging, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.19#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when Record Entries are merged (e.g., same patient, multiple sets of record entries).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.19#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization where Record Entries are merged.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.19#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of merged Record Entries.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.19#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the identifier for the source set of Record Entries.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.19#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the identifier for the target set of Record Entries.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.19#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the user merging Record Entries.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.19#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which merged Record Entries.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.19#08
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., merge).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.19#09
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time Record Entries are merged.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.19#10
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where Record Entries are merged.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.19#11
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for merging Record Entries.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.19#12
object.notes: The system MAY capture the data, document or other identifier for merged Record Entries.

object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when merged Record Entries are unmerged.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.20#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization where Record Entries are unmerged.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.20#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of unmerged Record Entries.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.20#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the identifier for the source set of Record Entries.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.20#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the identifier for the target set of Record Entries.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.20#07

object.name: TI.2.1.1.20#08
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., unmerge).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.20#11
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for unmerging Record Entries.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.20#12
object.notes: The system MAY capture the data, document or other identifier for unmerged Record Entries.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.21 Link Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry linking.$DE$Capture Record Entry linking, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.notes: The system SHOULD audit each occurrence when Record Entries are linked to another entry/object (e.g., Record Entries in an external system).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.21#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the organization where Record Entries are linked.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.21#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the patient who is subject of linked Record Entries.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.21#06

object.name: TI.2.1.1.21#07
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture date and time Record Entries are linked.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.21#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where Record Entries are linked.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.21#09

object.notes: The system SHOULD audit each occurrence when linked Record Entries are unlinked from another entry/object.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.22#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the organization where Record Entries are unlinked.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.22#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the patient who is subject of un-linked Record Entry.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.22#04
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the user unlinking Record Entries.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.22#05
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the system application which unlinked Record Entries.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.22#06
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., unlink).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.22#07
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture date and time Record Entries are unlinked.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.22#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where Record Entries are unlinked.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.22#09
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for unlinking Record Entries.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.23 Place Legal Hold on Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry placement on legal hold.$DE$Capture Record Entry placement on legal hold, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.23#01
object.notes: The system SHOULD audit each occurrence when a set of Record Entries are placed on legal hold.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.23#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the organization where Record Entries are placed on legal hold.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.23#03

object.name: TI.2.1.1.23#05

object.name: TI.2.1.1.23#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which placed Record Entries on legal hold.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.23#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., placed on legal hold).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.23#08
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time Record Entries are placed on legal hold.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.23#09
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) from which Record Entries are placed on legal hold.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.23#10
object.notes: The system MAY capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) in which Record Entries on legal hold is placed.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.23#11
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for placing Record Entries on legal hold.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.23#12
object.notes: The system MAY capture the data, document or other identifier for Record Entries placed on legal hold.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.24 Remove Legal Hold on Record Entry Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Record Entry release from legal hold.$DE$Capture Record Entry release from legal hold, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.1.24#01
object.notes: The system SHOULD audit each occurrence when a set of Record Entries are released from legal hold.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.24#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the organization where Record Entries are released from legal hold.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.24#03
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the patient who is subject of Record Entries released from legal hold.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.24#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the user releasing Record Entries from legal hold.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.24#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system application which released Record Entries from legal hold.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.24#06
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture the type of Record Event trigger (i.e., released from legal hold).

object.name: TI.2.1.1.24#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time Record Entries are released from legal hold.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.24#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture identity of the location (i.e., network address) where Record Entries are released from legal hold.

object.name: TI.2.1.1.24#09
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for releasing Record Entries from legal hold.

object.name: TI.2.1.2 Security Audit Triggers
object.notes: $ST$Manage Security Audit Triggers$DE$Security Audit Triggers are designed to capture security related events, both routine and exceptional, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.2#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to enter the reason that access control functions are being overridden.

object.name: TI.2.1.2#02
object.notes: The system MAY be able to provide the ability to detect security-relevant events that it mediates and generate audit records for them.

object.name: TI.2.1.2#03
object.notes: The system SHALL provide audit capabilities for recording access and usage of systems, data, and organizational resources.

object.name: TI.2.1.2#04
object.notes: The system SHALL provide audit capabilities to capture system events at the hardware and software architecture level.

object.name: TI.2.1.2#05
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to record system maintenance events for entry to and exit from the EHR system.

object.name: TI.2.1.2#06
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to record system maintenance events for remote access connections including those for system support and maintenance activities for security and access purposes.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.1 Security Event Security Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track Security event.$DE$Capture security events, both routine and exceptional, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.2.1#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when security events are detected according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.1#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.1#03
object.notes: IF known, THEN the system SHALL capture identity of the user.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.1#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.1#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the event initiating audit trigger.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.1#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time of the event initiating audit trigger.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.1#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the location (i.e., network address).

object.name: TI.2.1.2.1#08
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for the event initiating audit trigger.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.2 User Authentication to the System (Start user session) Security Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track user authentication to the system (start user session).$DE$Capture user authentication to the system (start user session), both routine and exceptional, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.2.2#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence of user authentication at logon (start session).

object.name: TI.2.1.2.2#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.2#03
object.notes: IF known, THEN the system SHALL capture identity of the user.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.2#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.2#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the event initiating audit trigger.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.2#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time of the event initiating audit trigger.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.2#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the location (i.e., network address).

object.name: TI.2.1.2.2#08
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the method of user authentication (e.g., user ID, password, biometrics, token, security question(s)).

object.name: TI.2.1.2.3 User Authentication (System Prompt for Password Change) Security Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track user authentication (system prompt for password change).$DE$Capture user authentication (system prompt for password change), both routine and exceptional, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.2.3#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence of user authentication when user is prompted to change password.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.3#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.3#03
object.notes: IF known, THEN the system SHALL capture identity of the user.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.3#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the identity of the system.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.3#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the event initiating audit trigger.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.3#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time of the event initiating audit trigger.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.3#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the location (i.e., network address).

object.name: TI.2.1.2.3#08
object.notes: IF password change successful, THEN the system SHALL capture the new password.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.4 User Request to Change Password Security Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track user request to change password.$DE$Capture user request to change password, both routine and exceptional, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.2.4#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence of user authentication when user requests password change.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.4#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.4#03
object.notes: IF known, THEN the system SHALL capture identity of the user.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.4#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.4#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the event initiating audit trigger.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.4#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time of the event initiating audit trigger.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.4#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the location (i.e., network address).

object.name: TI.2.1.2.4#08
object.notes: The system MAY capture the rationale for the event initiating audit trigger.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.4#09
object.notes: IF password change successful, THEN the system SHALL capture the new password.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.5 User Log Out (End user session) Security Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track user log out (end user session).$DE$Capture user log out (end user session), both routine and exceptional, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.2.5#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence of user logout (end session).

object.name: TI.2.1.2.5#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.5#03
object.notes: IF known, THEN the system SHALL capture identity of the user.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.5#04
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the system.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.5#05
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the event initiating audit trigger.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.5#06
object.notes: The system SHALL capture date and time of the event initiating audit trigger.

object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the location (i.e., network address).

object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track user attempts to access data (unsuccessful – access denied).$DE$Capture user attempts to access data (unsuccessful – access denied), both routine and exceptional, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track extraordinary user access (break the glass).$DE$Capture extraordinary user access (break the glass), both routine and exceptional, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.2.9 User Permissions (Authorization) Security Audit Trigger
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track user permissions (authorization).$DE$Capture user permissions (authorization), both routine and exceptional, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.2.9#01
object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence when user permissions (authorizations) are granted, removed or updated.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.9#02
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the organization.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.9#03

object.name: TI.2.1.2.9#07
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of the location (i.e., network address).

object.name: TI.2.1.2.9#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture the rationale for granting, removing or updating user permissions.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.9#09
object.notes: The system SHALL capture identity of user to whom permissions apply.

object.name: TI.2.1.2.9#10
object.notes: The system SHALL capture the new set of applicable user permissions (authorizations).

object.name: TI.2.1.3 System Audit Triggers
object.notes: $ST$Manage System Audit Triggers$DE$System Audit Triggers are designed to capture system related events, both routine and exceptional, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.3#01
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to record system maintenance events for loading new versions of, or changes to, the clinical system.

object.name: TI.2.1.3#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to record system maintenance events for loading new versions of codes and knowledge bases.

object.name: TI.2.1.3#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to record system maintenance events for creating and restoring of backup.

object.name: TI.2.1.3#04
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to audit events in the case of detection of corrupt or dirty data.

object.name: TI.2.1.3#05
object.notes: The system SHALL provide audit capabilities for recording access and usage of systems, data, and organizational resources.

object.name: TI.2.1.3#06
object.notes: The system SHALL provide audit capabilities to capture system events at the hardware and software architecture level.

object.name: TI.2.1.3#07
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to record system maintenance events for entry to and exit from the EHR system.

object.name: TI.2.1.3#08
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to record system maintenance events for remote access connections including those for system support and maintenance activities for security and access purposes.

object.name: TI.2.1.4 Clinical Audit Triggers
object.notes: $ST$Manage Clinical Audit Triggers$DE$Clinical Audit Triggers are designed to capture certain clinical events, both routine and exceptional, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.name: TI.2.1.4#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the capability to track all clinical alerts.

object.name: TI.2.1.4#02
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the capability to track all acknowledgements of clinically significant report changes.

object.name: TI.2.1.4#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to track when decision support alerts have been disabled.

object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Trigger initiated to track clinical alerts.$DE$Capture clinical alerts, both routine and exceptional, including key metadata (who, what, when, where, why).$EX$

object.notes: The system SHALL audit each occurrence of a clinical alert according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.notes: IF known, THEN the system SHALL capture identity of the user.

object.notes: The system SHALL capture the event initiating audit trigger.

object.name: TI.2.1.4.1#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture the rationale for the clinical alert.

object.name: TI.2.2 Audit Log Management
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Log$DE$Audit Triggers create Audit Log entries. Audit Log entries are typically managed as persistent evidence of events occurring over time, including events pertaining to record management, security, system operations and performance, key clinical situations.Audit log entries capture event details, including key metadata (who, what, when, where).Audit log functions fulfill log maintenance and persistence requirements according to scope of practice, organizational policy and jurisdictional law.$EX$

object.name: TI.2.2#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to capture audit log entries using a standards-based audit record format (for example RFC 3881).

object.name: TI.2.2#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to annotate or tag previously recorded audit log entries.

object.name: TI.2.2#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to securely store audit log entries metadata including related metadata.

object.name: TI.2.2#04
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to log access to audit log entries and/or metadata.

object.name: TI.2.2.1 Audit Log Indelibility
object.notes: $ST$Manage Audit Log Indelibility$DE$Audit logs must be maintained in a persistent and indelible form according to scope of practice, organizational policy and jurisdictional law.$EX$

object.name: TI.2.2.1#01
object.notes: The system SHALL manage each Audit Log entry as a persistent, indelible (unalterable) data object including all metadata.

object.name: TI.2.3 Audit Notification and Review
object.notes: $ST$Notify of Audit Events, Review Audit Log$DE$EHR system functions allow various methods of critical event notification (from audit triggers) as well as routine log review.Audit log notification and review functions implement requirements according to scope of practice, organizational policy and jurisdictional law.$EX$

object.name: TI.2.3#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to render a report based on audit log entries.

object.name: TI.2.3#02
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the capability to generate reports based on ranges of system date and time that audit log entries were captured.

object.name: TI.2.3#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to render audit log entry time stamps using UTC (based on ISO 8601).

object.name: TI.2.3#04
object.notes: The system SHALL allow emergency access log entry review based on criteria such as individual assignment or specified role, reasons, patient information/record entries according to organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.3 Registry and Directory Services
object.notes: $ST$Enable the use of registry services and directories to uniquely identify, locate and supply links for retrieval of information related to:- patients and providers for healthcare purposes; - payers, health plans, sponsors, and employers for administrative and financial purposes; - public health agencies for healthcare purposes, and- healthcare resources and devices for resource management purposes.$DE$Registry and directory service functions are critical to successfully managing the security, interoperability, and the consistency of the health record data across an EHR-S. These services enable the linking of relevant information across multiple information sources within, or external to, an EHR-S for use within an application. This applies to directories/registries internal to the EHR-S as well as directories/registries external to the EHR-S . Transmission may occur automatically or manually and may include small or large amounts of data. Directories and registries support communication between EHR Systems and may be organized hierarchically or in a federated fashion. For example, a patient being treated by a primary care physician for a chronic condition may become ill while out of town. The new provider’s EHR-S interrogates a local, regional, or national registry to find the patient’s previous records. From the primary care record, a remote EHR-S retrieves relevant information in conformance with applicable patient privacy and confidentiality rules.An example of local registry usage is an EHR-S application sending a query message to the Hospital Information System to retrieve a patient’s demographic data.$EX$

object.name: TI.3#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to manage internal registry services and directories.

object.name: TI.3#02
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to import from or transmit to external registry services and directories.

object.name: TI.3#03
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to securely transmit information to and import information from external registry services and directories.

object.name: TI.3#04
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to function TI.5.1 (Application and Structured-Document Interchange Standards) to transmit information to and receive information from external registry services and directories.

object.name: TI.3#05
object.notes: The system SHOULD capture and render local registry services and directory information through standards-based interfaces.

object.name: TI.3#06
object.notes: IF the system communicates with external registry services and directories (i.e., external to an EHR-S), THEN the system SHOULD capture and render information using standards-based interfaces.

object.name: TI.3#07
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to determine the unique identity of a patient through the use of internal and/or external registry services or directories.

object.name: TI.3#08
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to determine links to healthcare information through use of internal and/or external registry services or directories.

object.name: TI.3#09
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to determine the unique identity of a provider through the use of internal and/or external registry services or directories.

object.name: TI.3#10
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to determine the identity of payers, health plans and sponsors for administrative or financial purposes through the use of internal and/or external registry services or directories.

object.name: TI.3#11
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to determine the identity of employers for administrative or financial purposes through the use of internal and/or external registry services or directories.

object.name: TI.4 Standard Terminology and Terminology Services
object.notes: $ST$Support semantic interoperability through the use of standard terminologies, standard terminology models and standard terminology services.$DE$The purpose of supporting terminology standards and services is to enable semantic interoperability. Interoperability is demonstrated by the consistency of human and machine interpretation of shared data and reports. It includes the capture and support of consistent data for templates and decision support logic.Terminology standards pertain to concepts, representations, synonyms, relationships and computable (machine-readable) definitions. Terminology services provide a common way for managing and retrieving these items, including historically correct version interpretation. Terminology services need to support legal requirements for retrospective health record information and system data.$EX$

object.name: TI.4#01
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage patient disposition status configuration parameters.

object.name: TI.4#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage patient disposition statuses.

object.name: TI.4.1 Standard Terminology and Terminology Models
object.notes: $ST$Employ approved standard terminologies to ensure data correctness and to enable semantic interoperability (both within an enterprise and externally).Support a formal standard terminology model.$DE$Semantic interoperability requires standard terminologies combined with a formal standard information model. An example of an information model is the HL7 Reference Information Model. Another example is the ISO/EN 13606 Electronic Health Record Communication.A terminology provides semantic and computable identity to its concepts. Examples of terminologies that an EHR-S may support include: LOINC, SNOMED, ICD-9, ICD-10, and CPT-4.Terminologies are use-case dependent and may or may not be realm dependent. The key is that the standard be approved by all stakeholders. For example, terminologies for public health interoperability may differ from those for healthcare quality, administrative reporting, research, etc.Formal standard terminology models enable common semantic representations by describing relationships that exist between concepts within a terminology or in different terminologies, such as exemplified in the model descriptions contained in the HL7 Common Terminology Services specification.The clinical use of standard terminologies is greatly enhanced with the ability to perform hierarchical inference searches across coded concepts. Hierarchical Inference enables searches to be conducted across sets of coded concepts stored in an EHR-S. Relationships between concepts in the terminology are used in the search to recognize child concepts of a common parent. For example, there may be a parent concept, "penicillin containing preparations" which has numerous child concepts, each of which represents a preparation containing a specific form of penicillin (Penicillin V, Penicillin G, etc.). Therefore, a search may be conducted to find all patients taking any form of penicillin preparation.Clinical and other terminologies may be provided through a terminology service internal or external to an EHR-S. An example of a terminology service is described in the HL7 Common Terminology Services specification.$EX$

object.name: TI.4.1#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to receive and transmit data from and to other systems(internal or external to the EHR-S) using approved standard terminologies.

object.name: TI.4.1#02
object.notes: The system SHALL automatically determine that clinical terms and coded clinical data exist in an approved standard terminology.

object.name: TI.4.1#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to receive and transmit healthcare data using formal standard information models and approved standard terminologies.

object.name: TI.4.1#04
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage data using a formal standard terminology model.

object.name: TI.4.1#05
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to determine hierarchical inferences (e.g., subsumption across coded terminology concepts that are expressed using standard terminology models).

object.name: TI.4.1#06
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to manage terminology assets and supporting tools (internal or external to the EHR-S).

object.name: TI.4.1#07
object.notes: IF there is no recognized-standard terminology model available, THEN the system MAY provide the ability to manage data using a locally-defined standard terminology model.

object.name: TI.4.1#08
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to capture information into structured data formats using approved standard terminologies without the user requiring knowledge of the terminologies used.

object.name: TI.4.1#09
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to enter and present data using text forms that do not include cryptic or uncommon abbreviations.

object.name: TI.4.1#10
object.notes: The system SHOULD have the ability to present standard terminology terms in a language which is appropriate for the user.

object.name: TI.4.2 Maintenance and Versioning of Standard Terminologies
object.notes: $ST$Enable version control according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional policies to ensure maintenance of utilized terminology standards.This includes the ability to accommodate changes to terminology sets as the source terminology undergoes its natural update process (new codes, retired codes, redirected codes). Such changes need to be cascaded to clinical content embedded in templates, custom formularies, etc., as determined by existing policy.$DE$Version control allows for multiple sets or versions of the same terminology to exist and be distinctly recognized over time. Terminology standards are usually periodically updated, and concurrent use of different versions may be required. Ideally, the meaning of a concept never changes over time, but a concept can be deprecated, and replaced with a new concept in a new version. However, in some terminologies, the meaning of a concept can change over time. In any case, it is important that retrospective analysis and research maintains the ability to relate to the appropriate conceptual meanings. If the terminology encoding for a concept changes over time, it is also important that for legal health records, as well as for retrospective analysis and research, the different encodings can be correlated to ensure the permanence of the concept as originally captured. This does not necessarily imply that complete older versions of the terminology be kept in the EHR-S, only access to the changes needs to be maintained.$EX$

object.name: TI.4.2#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to manage data using different versions of terminology standards.

object.name: TI.4.2#02
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to update terminology standards.

object.name: TI.4.2#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD maintain relationships between modified concepts in the different versions of a terminology standard to allow preservation of interpretation over time.

object.name: TI.4.2#04
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to receive data from and transmit data to other systems that use known different versions of a terminology standard while preserving the meaning of that data.

object.name: TI.4.2#05
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to update terminologies to a deprecated status.

object.name: TI.4.2#06
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to update individual codes within a terminology to a deprecated status.

object.name: TI.4.2#07
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to automatically update terms with their equivalent when terminology is changed, where coded terminology content is embedded in clinical models (e.g., templates and custom formularies), when the terminology changes can be accomplished unambiguously, and if consistent with scope of practice, organizational policy, and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.4.2#08
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to enter and store new clinical content (via templates, custom formularies, etc.) using updated terminology.

object.name: TI.4.2#09
object.notes: The system SHALL maintain an audit log or a change history of versions used and dates implemented and updated to enable correct interpretation of historical data over time.

object.name: TI.4.3 Terminology Mapping
object.notes: $ST$Map or translate one terminology to another as needed by local, regional, national, or international interoperability requirements.$DE$The ability to map or translate one terminology to another is fundamental to an organization in an environment where several terminologies are in play with overlapping concepts.It is a common occurrence that data is captured using one terminology, but is shared using another terminology. For example, within a healthcare organization there may be a need to map overlapping terminology concepts (e.g. between an EHRS and an external laboratory system, or between an EHRS and a billing system).Realm specific (including local, regional, national or international) interoperability requirements can also determine the need for terminology mapping, and in many cases terminology mapping services (internal or external) can be used to satisfy these requirements.The interaction and mapping of terminologies may be called into question in a legal proceeding, when clinical decisions were documented and made based on mapped concepts.$EX$

object.name: TI.4.3#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to manage data using terminology maps which may be provided by terminology mapping services (internal or external).

object.name: TI.4.3#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to update terminology maps using standard terminology services (internal or external).

object.name: TI.4.3#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability for a user to determine the validity of terminology mappings using approved mapping techniques.

object.name: TI.4.3#04
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability for a user to determine custom terminology maps using approved mapping techniques where formal standard terminology maps are unavailable.

object.name: TI.5 Standards-Based Interoperability
object.notes: $ST$Provide automated health care delivery processes and seamless exchange of clinical, administrative, and financial information through standards-based solutions.$DE$Interoperability standards enable certain applications to be shared among EHR systems, resulting in a unified (logical) view of a given EHR system where several disparate systems may actually be participating transparently. Interoperability standards also enable certain information to be shared among EHR systems (including information that resides in regional, national, or international information exchanges). Interoperability standards also promote timely and efficient information capture, use, and re-use, often reducing the cumulative workload of the broad set of stakeholders.When health-related information is exchanged -- or when external applications are used to extend an EHR system -- the interoperability methods and underlying standards that were used in the process may need to be disclosed during a legal proceeding (especially when the resulting information becomes part of the patient's medical record).$EX$

object.name: TI.5.1 Application and Structured-Document Interchange Standards
object.notes: $ST$Support an EHR system's ability to operate seamlessly with systems that adhere to recognized application interchange standards. These systems include other EHR systems, subcomponents of an EHR system, or other (authorized, non-EHR) systems.$DE$Since a health care organization typically has various external and internal interoperability requirements, it must use a set of corresponding interoperability or interchange standards that will meet its connectivity and information structure, format, and semantic requirements. Information should be exchanged -- and applications should provide functionality -- in a manner that appears to be seamless to the user. To be specific, if data is received from an external source that requires a user to manually copy-and-paste that data into multiple parts of the system, the exchange is not considered to be "seamless".Examples of standards-based EHR information content and exchange methods include: ISO 13606 extracts, HL7 V2 messages, HL7 Clinical Document Architecture (CDA) documents, X12N healthcare transactions, and Digital Imaging and Communication in Medicine (DICOM) documents.Support for multiple interaction modes is needed to respond to differing levels of immediacy and types of exchange. For example, messaging is effective for many near-real time, asynchronous data exchange scenarios but may not be appropriate if the end-user is requesting an immediate response from a remote application. A variety of interaction modes are typically supported such as:- Unsolicited Notifications. E.g., Adam Everyman has arrived at the clinic for his scheduled appointment- Query/Response. E.g., Query: Is Adam Everyman known to the system? Response: Yes, Adam's medical record number is 12345678.- Service Request and Response. E.g., Request: Laboratory Order for “Fasting Blood Sugar”. Response: the results of the test.- Information Interchange between organizations (e.g. in a RHIO, or in a National Health System) - Structured/discrete clinical documents, e.g., Clinical Note- Unstructured clinical document, e.g., dictated surgical noteStandard terminology is a fundamental part of interoperability and is described in section IN.4. Using a formal explicit information model further optimizes interoperability. An example of an information model is the HL7 Reference Information Model (RIM). Organizations typically need to deal with more than one information model and may need to develop a mapping or a meta-model.$EX$

object.name: TI.5.1.1 Application Interchange Standards
object.notes: $ST$Support the ability to operate seamlessly with other systems by using applications and/or structured documents that adhere to interchange standards.$DE$Placeholder - Not Defined at this time$EX$

object.name: TI.5.1.1#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to receive and transmit information using interchange standards as required by realm / local -specific profiles and/or by recognized jurisdictional authorities.

object.name: TI.5.1.1#02
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to seamlessly perform interchange operations with other systems that adhere to interchange standards as required by realm / local -specific and/or by recognized jurisdictional authorities.

object.name: TI.5.1.1#03
object.notes: The system SHALL conform to functions under TI.4 (Standard Terminology and Terminology Services) to support terminology standards according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.5.1.1#04
object.notes: IF a standard information model is not available, THEN the system SHOULD provide the ability to exchange information with other systems in a seamless manner by using a formal explicit information model.

object.name: TI.5.1.1#05
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to exchange information with other systems by using an explicit formal information model and/or by using a standard coded terminology.

object.name: TI.5.1.1#06
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to receive and transmit data using standard, coded terminology.

object.name: TI.5.1.1#07
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to export data using an explicit and formal information model in accordance with industry and governmental-mandated standards.

object.name: TI.5.1.1#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD have the capability to import data using an explicit and formal information model in accordance with industry and governmental-mandated standards.

object.name: TI.5.1.1#09
object.notes: The system SHOULD have the ability to harmonize data with another system.

object.name: TI.5.1.1#10
object.notes: The system SHOULD have the ability to determine whether the information transmitted to another system has been successfully received by that other system.

object.name: TI.5.1.1#11
object.notes: The system SHALL store a log record of each data exchange (transaction) when transmitting information with external systems.

object.name: TI.5.1.2 Structured-Document Interchange Standards
object.notes: $ST$Support the management of structured documents.$DE$Structured documents represent an important method to facilitate the transfer of information to support care. Structured documents are also used to facilitate care transfers across domains, and to support patient care in RHIO environments. Structured documents have been purposed for the purposes of ED referral, transfer of care between EMS and ED systems, and transfers of care from ED to inpatient providers as well as back to ambulatory providers. Structured medical documents (including medical summaries) may reside in information systems external to the hospital enterprise. These documents are often sent from primary care physicians or clinics. $EX$

object.name: TI.5.1.2#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to receive, maintain and transmit structured documents.

object.name: TI.5.2 Interchange Standards Versioning and Maintenance
object.notes: $ST$Support various versions of an interchange standard.$DE$Interchange standards characteristically change throughout their lifecycles; those changes are often tagged with "version" numbers. EHR systems need to control the various versions of interchange standards that are used within an EHR implementation and accommodate changes that arise with each version.For example, if an organization migrates to version 2.5 of HL7's messaging standard, it may choose to utilize that version's specimen or blood bank information capabilities. The organization may also find that certain fields have been retained for backwards compatibility only or withdrawn altogether. The EHR-S needs to be able to handle all of these possibilities.Standards typically evolve in such a way as to protect backwards compatibility. On the other hand, sometimes there is little, or no, backwards compatibility when an organization may need to replace an entire standard with a new methodology. An example of this is migrating from HL7 v2 to HL7 v3.Interchange standards that are backward compatible support exchange among senders and receivers who are using different versions. Version control ensures that those sending information in a later version of a standard consider the difference in information content that can be interchanged effectively with receivers, who are capable of processing only earlier versions. That is, senders need to be aware of the information that receivers are unable to capture and adjust their business processes accordingly.Version control enables multiple versions of the same interchange standard to exist and be distinctly recognized over time. Since interchange standards are usually periodically updated, concurrent use of different versions may be required.Large (and/or federated) organizations typically need to use different versions of an interchange standard to meet internal organizational interoperability requirements.For example, the enterprise-wide standard might use HL7 v2.5 for Lab messages, but some regions of the enterprise might be at a lower level.It should be possible to retire deprecated interchange standards versions when applicable business cycles are completed while maintaining obsolete versions. An example use of this is for possible claims adjustment throughout the claim’s life cycle.When interchange standards change over time, it is important that retrospective analysis and research correlate and note gaps between the different versions’ information structures to support the permanence of concepts over time. An example use of this is the calculation of outcome or performance measures from persisted data stores where one version of a relevant interchange standard, e.g., CDA Release 1 captures the relevant data, e.g., discharge data, differently than CDA Release 2.$EX$

object.name: TI.5.2#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to use different versions of interchange standards.

object.name: TI.5.2#02
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to change (reconfigure) the way that data is transmitted as an interchange standard evolves over time and in accordance with business needs.

object.name: TI.5.2#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to deprecate an interchange standard.

object.name: TI.5.2#04
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to integrate with other systems that use previously-supported versions of an interoperability standard according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.5.3 Standards-Based Application Integration
object.notes: $ST$Integrate applications in a standards-based manner.$DE$An EHR-S often consists of multiple applications. Some of those applications may be within the EHR-S; others may be external to the EHR-S. The user of the EHR-S often benefits when those applications are integrated. Application integration can be accomplished in an ad-hoc fashion or in a standards- based fashion.The method(s) by which applications may be integrated within an organization depends on that organization’s approach to application integration. A given organization could conceivably employ multiple application integration approaches to meet various application integration requirements.Examples of standards-based application integration approaches include: - Desktop visual integration via HL7 Clinical Context Object Workgroup (CCOW) standards.- Workflow function integration via the Workflow Management Coalition (WfMC) standards.- Enterprise Information System Architecture integration of EHR systems via Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) standards.$EX$

object.name: TI.5.3#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to integrate applications in a standards-based fashion when the system is composed of and/or is extended by disparate applications.

object.name: TI.5.3#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to integrate user (or system) authentication for the purposes application context management (e.g., Graphical User Interface application integration via HL7's Context Management Standard from the Clinical Context Object Work Group (CCOW)).

object.name: TI.5.4 Interchange Agreements
object.notes: $ST$Support the use of Interchange Agreements to specify the rules, responsibilities, expectations, and methods by which Interchange Agreement partners may exchange information.$DE$Systems that wish to communicate with each other must agree on certain parameters/criteria that will govern an information exchange process. Interchange agreements enable partnering systems to discover, negotiate, and utilize those parameters/criteria. An EHR-S can use this information to define how data will be exchanged between the sending and the receiving partners. Interchange services and capabilities can be discovered in an automated fashion.Entity directories can be used to determine the address, profile, and data exchange requirements of known and/or potential Interchange Agreement partners. Entity registries can be used to determine the security, addressing, and reliability requirements between potential Interchange Agreement partnering systems.Examples of services that may be provided by the use of Interchange Agreements:- A new application can automatically determine the source of a patient's demographic information by using a Universal Description and Discovery Integration (UDDI) service. The new application can then retrieve the Web Services Description Language (WSDL) specification to discover the binding details.- Good Health Hospital, a member of AnyCounty LabNet, shares laboratory results with other partners. Good Health Hospital periodically queries LabNet's directory (UDDI) to determine whether new information providers have joined LabNet. When new information providers are discovered, the Good Health Hospital IT system establishes the appropriate service connections based upon the Service Description (WSDL).- A clinical research sponsor submits an interchange agreement to a registry. Various EHR systems access that registry to discover the clinical research sponsor's contact information.$EX$

object.name: TI.5.4#01
object.notes: The system SHALL exchange information with Interchange Agreement partners based on interoperability agreement descriptions.

object.name: TI.5.4#02
object.notes: IF an interchange agreement description specifies the use of a certain standard, THEN the system SHOULD exchange information using the standard specified by the interchange agreement description according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.5.4#03
object.notes: The system MAY conform to function TI.3 (Registry and Directory Services) to interact with registries and/or directories to determine the address, profile, and data exchange requirements of known and/or potential partners.

object.name: TI.5.4#04
object.notes: The system MAY analyze and present interchange service descriptions and capabilities according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.5.4#05
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage Interchange Agreements that have been established with Interchange Agreement partners.

object.name: TI.5.5 System Integration
object.notes: $ST$Support the integration of the EHR system with related systems.$DE$Within a given organization (for example, an institution, facility , or integrated care-delivery network), an EHR system may be directly integrated with other systems (for example, a Laboratory Information System, Radiology System, Pharmacy System, or Hospital Information System). Conversely, an EHR system may access these other systems indirectly by integrating with a system that serves as the central routing mechanism for the organization. For example, the EHR system may be integrated with the Hospital Information System which then routes the EHR system's orders to a laboratory, pharmacy, or radiology service.Depending on the type of information that is exchanged within an integrated-system environment, certain heuristics may be needed that will help govern the information exchange process. For example, an immunization order and a hearing test should be cancelled for a patient who recently died; a heuristic algorithm should manage that cancellation request from the EHR system to interested members within the integrated network. Another example is that certain information imported into a care plan should be exported to some members of the care team, while other members of the care team might only receive a notice that the new information exists.$EX$

object.name: TI.5.5#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to integrate the EHR system with other systems (e.g., a Laboratory Information System, Radiology System, Pharmacy System, or Hospital Information System) according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.5.5#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to exchange discrete information (e.g., problem list, medication, and/or allergy information) with an integrated system data repository.

object.name: TI.5.5#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to exchange clinical documents with an integrated system Clinical Document Repository.

object.name: TI.5.5#04
object.notes: The system MAY exchange information with systems that are integrated with the EHR system using heuristics that are defined by scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.6 Business Rules Management
object.notes: $ST$Manage the ability to create, update, delete, view, and version business rules including institutional preferences. Apply business rules from necessary points within an EHR-S to control system behavior. An EHR-S audits changes made to business rules, as well as compliance to and overrides of applied business rules.$DE$EHR-S business rule implementation functions include decision support, diagnostic support, workflow control, and access privileges, as well as system and user defaults and preferences. An EHR-S supports the ability of providers and institutions to customize decision support components such as triggers, rules, or algorithms, as well as the wording of alerts and advice to meet realm specific requirements and preferences. Examples of applied business rules include:- Suggesting diagnosis based on the combination of symptoms (flu-like symptoms combined with widened mediastinum suggesting anthrax);- Classifying a pregnant patient as high risk due to factors such as age, health status, and prior pregnancy outcomes;- Sending an update to an immunization registry when a vaccination is administered;- Limiting access to mental health information to authorized providers;- Establishing system level defaults such as for vocabulary data sets to be implemented; and- Establishing user level preferences such as allowing the use of health information for research purposes.$EX$

object.name: TI.6#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to manage business rules.

object.name: TI.6#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to enter, import, or receive business rules to guide system behavior.

object.name: TI.6#03
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to maintain business rules and their components.

object.name: TI.6#04
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to tag decision support rules as inactive / obsolete or to remove them according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.6#05
object.notes: The system SHOULD support the ability to render business rules.

object.name: TI.6#06
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage diagnostic decision support rules that guide system behavior according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.6#07
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage workflow control rules that guide system behavior according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.6#08
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage access privilege rules that guide system behavior according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.6#09
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage other rules (for example, monitoring rules, user defaults rules and preferences rule) that guide system behavior according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.6#10
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to determine system behavior based upon defined business rules.

object.name: TI.7 Workflow Management
object.notes: $ST$Support workflow management functions including both the management and set up of work queues, personnel lists, and system interfaces as well as the implementation functions that use workflow-related business rules to direct the flow of work assignments.$DE$Workflow management functions that an EHR-S supports include:-Distribution of information to and from internal and external parties;-Support for task-management as well as parallel and serial task distribution;-Support for notification and task routing based on system triggers; and-Support for task assignments, escalations and redirection in accordance with business rules.Workflow definitions and management may be implemented by a designated application or distributed across an EHR-S.$EX$

object.name: TI.7#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to manage workflow business rules including work queues, personnel lists, and system interfaces.

object.name: TI.7#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to determine workflow assignments based on workflow-related business rules.

object.name: TI.7#03
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to manage human resources (i.e., personnel lists) for workflow queues.

object.name: TI.7#04
object.notes: The system MAY exchange information with external systems (for example, Human Resources system or Staff Management system) to support the management of human resources.

object.name: TI.7#05
object.notes: The system MAY exchange information with external systems (for example, Human Resources system or Staff Management system ) to support the management of workflow queues (task lists).

object.name: TI.7#06
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to exchange workflow related information with an external system.

object.name: TI.7#07
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to render notifications and tasks based on system triggers.

object.name: TI.7#08
object.notes: The system MAY determine and render an updated priority of tasks on the workflow (task list) queue in accordance with business rules, and according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.7#09
object.notes: The system MAY determine and render an update to the tasks and/or execution path on the workflow (task list) queue in accordance with business rules, and according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.7#10
object.notes: The system MAY determine and render an update to the assignment of the resources to workflow (task list) queue in accordance with business rules, and according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.7#11
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to render a notification of a workflow update.

object.name: TI.7#12
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to render a notification of a workflow update including the details of the update.

object.name: TI.7#13
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to transmit a workflow (task list) queue update request to an external system.

object.name: TI.7#14
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to receive a workflow (task list) queue update response from an external system.

object.name: TI.8 Database Backup and Recovery
object.notes: $ST$Provide for the ability to backup and recover the EHR system.$DE$To enable the preservation of the EHR database and it's data, functionality needs to be present to record a copy of the database and it's contents to offline media as well as the recovery of the system from a backup copy and resumption of normal system operation. The backup must preserve both data as well as database structure and definition information sufficient to recover a complete functional EHR system. Database components may include, but not be limited to application data, security credentials, log/audit files, and programs; ultimately all EHR components necessary to provide a full and complete operating environment. Finally, the backup must be capable of being used during recovery processing to restore an exact copy of the EHR system as of a particular instant in time. This is a requirement to be able to preserve logical consistency of information within the recovered EHR system.In providing for this capability the system may Include multiple backup and/or redundancy solutions such as fail-over architecture, database journaling, transaction processing, etc.The backup and recovery function must address both physical system failure (i.e. failure of EHR system hardware) as well as logical system failure (e.g. database corruption).To support the requirement that the EHR system be available whenever it is needed within the design parameters of the system and provide reliability and redundancy of the EHR database and it's data, the backup function shall not impact user functionality or appreciably impact user performance.The backup function may include features which permit multiple processes and technologies to perform it's task. This may include multiple backup technologies such as tape, disk, cloud, etc. Also, multiple architectures such as redundancy, online, near-line and off-line media.$EX$

object.name: TI.8#01
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to backup and recover EHR information according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.8#02
object.notes: The system SHALL provide the ability to backup and recover all database contents including programs and all software components necessary to permit a complete EHR to be recovered. (i.e., 'full' backup and recovery)

object.name: TI.8#03
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to backup and recover EHR information using alternative backup methods in addition to a full backup/recovery (e.g., incremental, differential, reverse delta, or continuous).

object.name: TI.8#04
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to backup EHR information according to a defined schedule of storage media rotation.

object.name: TI.8#05
object.notes: IF the EHR user requirements specify that the EHR system be available continuously, THEN the system SHALL provide the ability to backup EHR information concurrently with the normal operation of the EHR application.

object.name: TI.8#06
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to backup EHR information to a remote location.

object.name: TI.8#07
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to backup EHR information to more than one storage media (e.g., disk, tape, or cloud).

object.name: TI.8#08
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to encrypt backup data.

object.name: TI.9 System Management Operations and Performance
object.notes: $ST$Manage the change of status of an external facility and the ability to access, render and determine information related to Service Level Agreement.$DE$A health care delivery relies on services provided by other external facilities such as laboratories or Long Term Care facilities. The status of those facilities is subject to change for example: power outage, flooding or overcapacity. Therefore, the EHR system needs to capture the status of the external facilities, notify appropriate individuals / organizations or even change the workflow based on established business rules. Change of the status of an external facility is patient safety concern because a provider may need to adjust patient care or care workflows accordingly. For example, changes of status of external facility include: laboratory no longer accredited, laboratory power outage, Long Term Care facility at overcapacity. If laboratory loses accreditation an administrator needs to be notified to adjust the workflow. If status change is anticipated on regular basis, the system may automatically trigger workflow adjustment according to established business rules that take into consideration the status of the external facility. The example for later, the local Long Term Care facility may routinely exceed the capacity on the weekends; therefore, the business rule will accommodate for automatic workflow adjustments. A provider may need to be aware of certain Service Level Agreement information in order to mitigate patient safety-related risks that depend on system availability or system performance.$EX$

object.name: TI.9#01
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage the change of status of an external facility.

object.name: TI.9#02
object.notes: The system SHOULD provide the ability to manage Service Level Agreement information according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.

object.name: TI.9#03
object.notes: The system MAY provide the ability to render system availability statistics and system performance statistics as specified in the Service Level Agreement according to scope of practice, organizational policy and/or jurisdictional law.
